articles.headline: Buffett Offers Aid on Bonds, but at a Price
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor made clear that his offer of a lifeline to three insurance companies battered by the subprime crisis would not come cheap.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor made clear that his offer of a lifeline to three insurance companies battered by the subprime crisis would not come cheap.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett volunteered on Tuesday to rescue Wall Street from its latest looming crisis.

articles.headline: In Price and Supply, Wheat Is the Unstable Staple
articles.snippet: With demand soaring abroad and droughts crimping supply, the world’s wheat stockpiles have fallen to their lowest level in 30 years.
articles.abstract: With demand soaring abroad and droughts crimping supply, the world’s wheat stockpiles have fallen to their lowest level in 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  For decades, wheat was a commodity no American needed to think much about, except the farmers who grew it. The grain was usually plentiful and prices were low.

articles.headline: Quitting Facebook Gets Easier
articles.snippet: Facebook modified its help pages to tell people that if they wanted to remove their accounts entirely, they can direct the company by e-mail to have it done.
articles.abstract: Facebook modified its help pages to tell people that if they wanted to remove their accounts entirely, they can direct the company by e-mail to have it done.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aiming to address the privacy concerns of disenchanted users, Facebook.com said on Tuesday that it was trying to make it easier for people to delete their accounts permanently from the social networking site.

articles.headline: Senate Votes to Expand Spy Powers
articles.snippet: The vote, a major victory for the White House, would also give legal protection to phone companies that cooperated in a program of warrantless eavesdropping.
articles.abstract: The vote, a major victory for the White House, would also give legal protection to phone companies that cooperated in a program of warrantless eavesdropping.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After more than a year of wrangling, the Senate handed the White House a major victory on Tuesday by voting to broaden the government’s spy powers and to give legal protection to phone companies that cooperated in President Bush’s program of eavesdropping without warrants.

articles.headline: Religion Joins Custody Cases, to Judges’ Unease
articles.snippet: Child-custody conflicts over religion are increasing, but constitutional issues make them hard for courts to resolve.
articles.abstract: Child-custody conflicts over religion are increasing, but constitutional issues make them hard for courts to resolve.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Ala.  On a January night nine years ago, Laura Snider was saved.

articles.headline: Obama and McCain Sweep 3 Primaries
articles.snippet: Barack Obama extended his winning streak over Hillary Rodham Clinton, while John McCain countered recent victories by Mike Huckabee.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama extended his winning streak over Hillary Rodham Clinton, while John McCain countered recent victories by Mike Huckabee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama rolled to victory by large margins in Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia on Tuesday, extending his winning streak over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to eight Democratic nominating contests.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: Limbo for U.S. Women Reporting Iraq Assaults
articles.snippet: Women who say they were sexually assaulted in Iraq by co-workers have found themselves unable to seek justice.
articles.abstract: Women who say they were sexually assaulted in Iraq by co-workers have found themselves unable to seek justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Mary Beth Kineston, an Ohio resident who went to Iraq to drive trucks, thought she had endured the worst when her supply convoy was ambushed in April 2004. After car bombs exploded and insurgents began firing on the road between Baghdad and Balad, she and other military contractors were saved only when Army Black Hawk helicopters arrived.

articles.headline: Tale of Dead Texas Dog Bites Mayor Who Told It
articles.snippet: A South Texas mayor, Grace Saenz-Lopez, and her twin sister are accused of dog rustling.
articles.abstract: A South Texas mayor, Grace Saenz-Lopez, and her twin sister are accused of dog rustling.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALICE, Tex.  Rustling has been frowned upon in this South Texas cow and cotton town since long before it was named for the youngest daughter of the founder of the nearby King Ranch.

articles.headline: G.M. Offers Buyouts to 74,000
articles.snippet: The buyout offer, which covers G.M.’s entire unionized work force, came as G.M. announced a $722 million fourth-quarter loss.
articles.abstract: The buyout offer, which covers G.M.’s entire unionized work force, came as G.M. announced a $722 million fourth-quarter loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A surprisingly tough fourth quarter and a gloomy outlook for the United States market prompted General Motors to offer buyouts Tuesday to its entire unionized work force.

articles.headline: Looking for Sure Political Bets at Online Prediction Market
articles.snippet: The Intrade Web site has become expert at predicting election results. Or has it?
articles.abstract: The Intrade Web site has become expert at predicting election results. Or has it?
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a professional poker player in Queens named Serge Ravitch who is convinced that he can make money off this year’s presidential election. But to explain what he’s up to, I want to start with a story about last week’s Democratic primary in California.

articles.headline: Southwest. Way Southwest.
articles.snippet: An airline success story in an otherwise grim industry tries to keep its inner quirk.
articles.abstract: An airline success story in an otherwise grim industry tries to keep its inner quirk.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  Southwest Airlines, with a raucous corporate culture that is the exception in the grim airline industry, stands to look even wilder as some of its big competitors contemplate mergers that would only further muddy their corporate identities.
